Package net.royalur

Class Game<P extends Piece,S extends PlayerState,R extends Roll>

java.lang.Object
net.royalur.Game<P,S,R>
Type Parameters:
P - The type of pieces that are stored on the board.
S - The type of state that is stored for each player.
R - The type of rolls that may be made.
public class Game<P extends Piece,S extends PlayerState,R extends Roll> extends Object
A game of the Royal Game of Ur. Provides methods to allow the playing of games, and methods to support the retrieval of history about the moves that were made.

      @Nonnull public List<GameState<P,S,R>> getStates()

    • makeMove

      public void makeMove(@Nonnull Move<P> move)
      Applies the move move to update the state of the game. This does not check whether the move is valid.
      Parameters:
      move - The move to make from the current state of the game.

    • makeMove

      Moves the piece piece, and updates the state of the game.
      Parameters:

    • getActionStates

      @Nonnull public List<ActionGameState<P,S,R,?>> getActionStates()
      Retrieves the states that represent the actions that have been made so far in the game. The last state in the list represents the last action that was taken in this game.
      Returns:
      The states that represent the actions that have been made so far in the game.

    • getLandmarkStates

      @Nonnull public List<GameState<P,S,R>> getLandmarkStates()
      Retrieves all moves that were made in the game, as well as the current state of the game. These states are considered landmark states as they contain all the information required to recreate everything that happened in the game so far.

    • isPlayable

      public boolean isPlayable()
      Determines whether the game is currently in a playable state.
      Returns:
      Whether the game is currently in a playable state.

    • getCurrentPlayableState

      @Nonnull public PlayableGameState<P,S,R,?> getCurrentPlayableState()
      Retrieves the current state of this game as a PlayableGameState. This will throw an error if the game is not in a playable state.
      Returns:
      The playable state that the game is currently in.

    • isWaitingForRoll

      public boolean isWaitingForRoll()
      Determines whether the game is currently in a state that is waiting for a roll from a player.
      Returns:
      Whether the game is currently in a state that is waiting for a roll from a player.

    • getCurrentWaitingForRollState

      @Nonnull public WaitingForRollGameState<P,S,R> getCurrentWaitingForRollState()
      Retrieves the current state of this game as an instance of WaitingForRollGameState. This will throw an error if the game is not in a state that is waiting for a roll from a player.
      Returns:
      The waiting for roll state that the game is currently in.

      @Nonnull public WinGameState<P,S,R> getCurrentWinState()

      Returns:
      The win state that the game is currently in.

    • builder

      @Nonnull public static <R extends Roll> GameBuilder<Piece,PlayerState,R> builder(GameSettings<R> settings)
      Creates a builder to assist in constructing games with custom settings.
      Parameters:
      settings - The settings to initialise the builder with.
      Returns:
      A builder to assist in constructing games with custom settings.

    • create

      @Nonnull public static <R extends Roll> Game<Piece,PlayerState,R> create(GameSettings<R> settings)
      Creates a standard game with custom settings.
      Parameters:
      settings - The settings to use for the game.
      Returns:
      A game with custom settings.

    • builder

      @Nonnull public static GameBuilder<Piece,PlayerState,Roll> builder()
      Creates a builder to assist in constructing games with custom settings. Provides a builder that is set up to produce games using the Finkel rule set by default.
      Returns:
      A builder to assist in constructing games with custom settings.

    • createFinkel

      @Nonnull public static Game<Piece,PlayerState,Roll> createFinkel()
      Creates a standard game that follows the rules proposed by Irving Finkel. This uses the simple rules, the standard board shape, Bell's path, safe rosette tiles, the standard dice, and seven starting pieces per player.
      Returns:
      A game that follows Irving Finkel's proposed simple rules.

    • createMasters

      @Nonnull public static Game<Piece,PlayerState,Roll> createMasters()
      Creates a standard game that follows the rules proposed by James Masters. This uses the simple rules, the standard board shape, Bell's path, unsafe rosette tiles, the standard dice, and seven starting pieces per player.
      Returns:
      A game that follows Irving Finkel's proposed simple rules.

    • createAseb

      @Nonnull public static Game<Piece,PlayerState,Roll> createAseb()
      Creates a game of Aseb. This uses the simple rules, the Aseb board shape, the Aseb paths, the standard dice, and five starting pieces per player.
      Returns:
      A game of Aseb.
